review.title: The Utility of Hedged Assertions in the Emergence of Shared Categorical Labels
review.abstract: We investigate the emergence of shared concepts in a community of language users using a multi-agent simulation. We extend results showing that negated assertions are of use in developing shared categories, to include assertions modified by linguistic hedges. Results show that using hedged assertions positively affects the emergence of shared categories in two distinct ways. Firstly, using contraction hedges like `very' gives better convergence over time. Secondly, using expansion hedges such as `quite' reduces concept overlap. However, both these improvements come at a cost of slower speed of development.
histories: AISB 2013, updated to include cross-reference to previous work
review.COMMENTS: AISB 2013, updated to include cross-reference to previous work

metadata.title: The Utility of Hedged Assertions in the Emergence of Shared Categorical Labels

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: An evolutionary approach to semantics enables the development of flexible, variable concepts that can be learned through interaction and change over time. [13] This approach is explored by Eyre and Lawry in [2], in which they develop a model of language development based on the label semantics framework. They show that the use of a mixture of positive and negated assertions enables the development of languages that are both shared and effectively distinguish between elements within the environment. We expand this work to include assertions that have been modified by the words "very" and "quite" and show that this improves performance in two respects. Using the hedging "very" improves the level of convergence achieved. The use of hedging "quite" reduces the overlap within an agent's label set. We describe in detail the theoretical approach to concepts and linguistic assurances in the rest of this section.

sections.heading: 1.1 A representation model for concepts
sections.text: This concept is based on experimental results in which human subjects were found to view belonging to a concept as a matter of degree, with some objects having a higher affiliation than others [11]. Fuzzy-set theory [15] in which an object x has a staggered affiliation to a prototype. This approach is based on experimental results in which human subjects were found to consider belonging to a concept as a matter of degree, but numerous objections were raised to its suitability. [10, 12, 5].1 University of Bristol, England, e-mail: martha.lewis @ bristol.ac.com, j.lawry @ bristol.ac.ukConceptual Spaces Theory renders concepts as convex regions of conceptual space - a geometric structure with physical distance.

sections.heading: 1.2 Linguistic hedges
sections.text: Hedges are words or phrases such as "very," "strictly speaking," that modify the scope of a concept. In particular, "very," "quite," or "rather," contract or expand the scope of a concept, so that, for example, "very large" applies to fewer people than "large," whereas "quite large" applies to more. In vague set theory, we expect that "very large" should always be less than "high." Therefore, anyone who can be described as "very large" can also be described as "high." Zadeh [16] uses operations of concentration and dilation to reflect these ideas. Concentration is described as "very large," as "high," and dilation is often presented as "high."

sections.heading: 2 METHODS
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1 Overview
sections.text: To investigate the utility of shared claims, we implement a multi-agent simulation of a version of the category game [14], following [2], in which divided categories evolve over time as a result of the interactions of the users of the categories. Agents use labels to describe a conceptual space. At each time step, agents are randomly paired into speaker and listener, and each pair is given a specific element x *. The speaker makes a claim regarding the element based on his label set. The listener then updates his own label set to be more similar to that of the speaker, based on this claim and a parameter w that can be imagined as the age of the speaker. The update made by the speaker is a combination of shifting the prototype of the relevant label and changing the size of the threshold. The goal is for label sets in the population to converge to a common group of shared categories after a number of timesteps.

sections.heading: 2.2 Conceptual models
sections.text: At the beginning of the simulations, the Pi thresholds are evenly distributed in space. Thresholds εi are also randomly initiated and considered as a multiple of a base threshold ε. APD measures the difference between the labeling packages in the community, and ALO indicates to what extent the concepts of an active substance overlap. We are looking for low values for each labeling size. APD is calculated using Haussdorff distance between two quarters as in equation 1.

sections.heading: 2.6 Simulation process
sections.text: Simulations with n = 100 agents were performed for T = 104 time steps. Agent weights w = 0.2, 0.8 were updated at each time step in steps of 1 / T. Whenever the agents with random labels and w = 0.2 are reborn, 20 simulations are performed for each reported combination of parameters. [2] show that the performance of the system changes when pp [0.5, 0.6] changes from low ALO and high APD to about pp = 0.56. We performed simulations in a slightly extended comparison range, using the previous probabilities pv = 0, pb = 1, pq = 0 of the assertion of the various hedges to be "very," "fundamental" and "quite." To investigate the effects of using contraction hedges, we run simulations with parameters pv = 0, b = 0.7, pv = 0.2 = 0.0.

sections.heading: 3 RESULTS
sections.text: Results show the performance of both metrics after 104 simulation phases. < p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p > p

sections.heading: 4 DISCUSSION
sections.text: These results show that in a model of language development in a population, hedged claims can improve both the level of convergence to common language as well as the average pair difference between label sets (APD) and, to some extent, the discriminatory power of individual label sets as measured by average label overlap (ALO).The two different types of hedges improve performance in different ways. If overall convergence is important, a high prior likelihood of assertion of contraction hedges should be used to improve the performance of APD metrics. Conversely, if the ability of agents to distinguish precisely between objects in the environment is more important, then expansion edges, along with lower probabilities of assertion of positive labels, should be used to maintain a low level of ALO while improved performance is based on APD metrics.

sections.heading: 5 CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: We have studied the utility of sound claims in developing a common language and have shown that it improves the ability of actors to make sound claims to develop common categories in two ways. Firstly, the use of contraction safeguards, i.e. words such as "very," enables a higher degree of convergence to common categories, while the degree of overlap between labels slightly improves. Secondly, the use of expansion safeguards, or words such as "well," allows the development of label sets that are more discriminatory to the environment and also exhibit a higher degree of convergence. However, both improvements go hand in hand with a slower rate of development of common labels. It may be possible to improve these speeds by adjusting other parameters such as the actors "age span or the values of the safeguards used.

referenceMentions.context: 1 INTRODUCTION An evolutionary approach to semantics enables the development in robots and autonomous agents of flexible, mutable concepts that could be learnt through interaction and can change over time [13].
This approach is investigated by Eyre and Lawry in [2], in which they develop a model of language evolution based in the label semantics framework.
1 A representation model for concepts We model concepts within the label semantics framework [7, 8], combined with prototype theory [11] and the conceptual spaces model of concepts [3].

1 A representation model for concepts We model concepts within the label semantics framework [7, 8], combined with prototype theory [11] and the conceptual spaces model of concepts [3].
This approach is based on experimental results where human subjects were found to view membership in a concept as a matter of degree, with some objects having higher membership than others [11].
Fuzzy set theory [15], in which an object x has a graded membership μL(x) in a concept L, was proposed as a formalism for prototype theory.
However, numerous objections to its suitability have been made [10, 12, 6, 5, 4].
However, numerous objections to its suitability have been made [10, 12, 6, 5, 4].

However, numerous objections to its suitability have been made [10, 12, 6, 5, 4].
Label semantics [7] is a random set approach to concepts which quantifies an agent’s uncertainty about the extent of application of a concept.
We refer to this as subjective uncertainty [8] to emphasise that it concerns the definition of concepts and categories, in contrast to stochastic uncertainty which concerns the state of the world.

Lawry and Tang [8] combine the label semantics approach with conceptual spaces and prototype theory, to give a formalisation of concepts as based on a prototype and a threshold, located in a conceptual space.
This appropriateness measure is similar to Zadeh’s description of fuzzy membership in a concept [15].
Zadeh [16] uses operations of concentration and dilation to render these ideas.

However, we argue, as do [1], that Zadeh’s formulae are, to an extent, arbitrary, since the notion of taking a power of a membership value does not correspond to anything that language users might do.
As with [1], we take a semantic approach.

In [9], we propose that a concept ‘very L’ or ‘quite L’ be rendered by considering that the prototype of ‘very/quite L’ is equal to that of the base concept L, but that the threshold of the hedged concept ‘very/quite L’ is respectively smaller or larger than that of the base concept.
We implement this model in a version of the multi-agent simulation created in [2] in order to investigate how the use of these hedges in a model of language helps

To investigate the utility of hedged assertions we implement a multiagent simulation of a version of the category game [14], following [2], in which shared categories develop over time as a result of the interactions of the category users.

One way of determining mx is via the consonant selection function introduced in [8].

metadata.abstractText: We investigate the emergence of shared concepts in a community of language users using a multi-agent simulation. We extend results showing that negated assertions are of use in developing shared categories, to include assertions modified by linguistic hedges. Results show that using hedged assertions positively affects the emergence of shared categories in two distinct ways. Firstly, using contraction hedges like ‘very’ gives better convergence over time. Secondly, using expansion hedges such as ‘quite’ reduces concept overlap. However, both these improvements come at a cost of slower speed of development.
